1:28s: you’re BRILLIANT.

X^0 = 1

1 = your “assumption” of what X “represents”.

Without an “assumption”. There is “nothing” to “measure”. Ergo, you’re “in the void” - what us “computer scientists” call “a null value”, and you have no “assumption”, X does not “exist” and your “rule” about x^0=1 falls apart. It ONLY “works” when you “assume” “something”.

“Something” cannot come from “nothing”. It must already “exist”. And, therefore, when you try to “measure”/model it, X^0=1. Lose your assumption, you’re in “no man’s land”.
So 0 divided by zero is one.

If you couldn't follow what he was talking about at 9:28 ,here it is.

Now look at the frame of 9:28
Let 3t be equal to g
d(e^g)/dg=e^g as we know derivative of e^g should be itself, right?
Now let's multiply dg on both sides
We get , d(e^g)=e^g(dg)
Let's put the value of g which we had supposed earlier.
d(e^(3t))=e^(3t)(d(3t))
Derivative of 3t would be 3 ofcourse
Finally , d(e^(3t))=(3)e^(3t)
And this does not work for only 3 but any constant like it .
Therefore, d(e^(nt))=(n)e^(nt)
For n to be any constant.
Hope this helped.

The video is great, yet the expressions with interest rate don’t look right :)

Let M denote the initial amount of money (a constant), M(t) denote amount of money at time t, r – interest rate over a unit of time t.

Then, assuming compound interest accrual, M(t) = M*(1+r)^t, and dM(t)/dt=(M*(1+r)^(t+dt)-M*(1+r)^t)/dt=M*(1+r)^t((1+r)^dt-1)/dt=M*ln(1+r)*(1+r)^t.

If we assume continuous compounding, M(t) = M*(1+r/n)^(n*t) as n goes to infinity, we will get a slightly different expression: M(t) = M*exp(r*t), dM(t)/dt = M*r*exp(r*t)

This is my favourite (Canadian spelling) of all time of your many fantastic videos, Grant. The continuous compounding formula is M(t)=m*e^(rt) and dM(t)/dt = m*r*e^(rt). An annual rate formula would be M(t) = m*(1+r)^t which is equal to m*e^(t*ln(1+r)) and the derivative of that function has no meaning because it is not a continuous function. So, while I love this video for the discussion of transformation properties of exponential functions, this video has some hair on it.

One easy way to mathematically look at it even tho it's easy and anyone can do it is :
M(t) = a^t
Taking ln on both sides
Ln [M(t)]= t*(ln a)
Now differentiating,
[1/M(t)]* d[M(t)/dt] = ln a
Hence ,
D/dt[M(t)] = M(t)*(ln a)
Hence for different values of a it'll give the answer correspondingly

Hey sth that I've just realised that I think can help to understand this better- as he says in the video (if I recall correctly, I've actually watched it a while ago) we are looking for a number for which the derivative of a^x is a^x. The derivative is a proportion between an infinitely small change in the function and the change in input that's causing it. So let's say that the change in input is not infinitely small- for example one. Then let's look for a number, for which this "derivative" has the property we want. a^(x+1)=a^x+a^x*1, a=2. If we try the change of input equal to 2, we get √3. We want to see what we get as the change in input approaches 0, so as we are getting closer to the actual derivative

Hi, Grant.

While watching this video, I thought of an interesting illustration that you might want to know about.

Choose a point (a,b) on the graph of a differentiable function f, and draw the triangle whose sides are (1) the tangent line (y-f(a))/(x-a)=f'(a) to f at (a,f(a), (2) the vertical line x=a through (a,f(a)), and (3) the x-axis y=0. Then the base of the triangle has (signed) length f(a)/f'(a).

For the exponential function e^x, the base always has length 1. So if you slide a line segment of length 1 back and forth along the x-axis, it can project this triangle up toward the graph of the function.

In respect of looking for something visual (that's not too abysmal):

I sort of explained this to someone once - that the derivative of 2^t is a constant proportional to 2^t - by considering the tenth root of 2. For every interval of size 1, the rate of increase of 2^(1/10)^t is some fixed proportion of itself. But it's obvious 2^(1/10)^t is simply the curve 2^t stretched out horizontally by a factor of 10 because you can chop that 1/10th into hundredth roots - as fine as you like. That the curve n^t is smooth and always increasing sort of follows from the fact that you can chop it up in this way.

But wait - what if the 29th roots of 2 followed a completely different path to the 31st roots of 2? This doesn't happen, because we can take the lowest common multiple of 29 and 31 and make a curve of the 891th rooths of 2. This has a nice smooth stepwise curve, and the curves traced out by the 31st and the 29rth roots all lie on it. But we are still working only with rational numbers.

With respect to the value of e, I stated with the idea that if this constant is a constant over the whole curve, then its average over an interval of the curve must be greater than the value at the sart of the interval, and less than the value at the end of the interval. And the avreage over an interval is simply the slope of the line connecting the two points.

We can demonstrate by inspecting the curves that the constant of proportionality for 2^t must be < 1, because the average height of the curve 2^t between 1 and 0 is >1, but the average rate of growth of 2^t between 0 and 1 is 1.

Similarly, we can demonstrate by inspection that the constant of proportionality for 3^x must be >1, because the average rate of growth between 0 and 1 is 2, but the average height is slightly <2 because the curve has a curve to it.

If we the proportionality constant is a smooth increasing function of the base, then there must be some number between 2 and 3 for which this constant is unity, and there you go.

One of the important things about e is that although you can make sense of rational exponents of rational numbers in terms of roots, all the numbers 2^a and 3^b - for rational a and b - are incommensurable. You can't get from one to the other, each prime number is a base of its own world of exponential values. e and natural logs forms a bridge between these worlds and fills in all the missing non-rational exponents.

Didn’t see this mentioned in the video. I think this is a more enlightening way of deriving the exponential derivative. It doesn’t require already knowing what e is.

You start with the same setup but this time with an arbitrary base a.
y’ = a^t * lim h->0 {(a^h - 1) / h}

You notice the term (a^h - 1) / h converges to some finite value. So we’ll let it converge to 1 since thats a nice number and it’ll mean y=y’

(a^h - 1) / h = 1

Solve for a

a = lim h->0 { (1 + h)^(1/h) }

Which might look familiar because its an identity for e. So the exponential with its derivative being itself is e^x

I’m not sure how rigorous this is but it gives the right answer.

Let's do some proving! :)
Let A be a constant, like 2 was in the video.
So, the derivative of A^x is just the limit of (A^(x+h)-A^h)/h, where h is approaching 0. (This is basically the same as dt was in the video.) Now we can take A^x out of the limit leaving us with the limit of (A^h-1)/h where h→0. Let z be A^h-1. With this, z+1=A^h. Let's take some kind of logarithm of both sides. I will use the natural logarithm for this (you will see why I do this later). From this, h=ln(z+1)/ln(A).
We know that as h→0, z→0 too because z=A^h-1
With this substitution we have:
/ z*ln(A) \
A^x*lim | --------------|
z→0 \ ln(z+1) /
We can now take ln(A) out of the limit so now we have:
/ z \
A^x*ln(A)*lim | ------------- |
z→0 \ ln(z+1) /
Now all we need to make sense of is the limit of z/ln(z+1) where z approaches 0 and we have the full derivative. If we take z into the logarithm, we have the following limit:
/ 1 \
lim | -------------------|
z→0 \ ln((z+1)^z) /
If we take the limit inside the logarithm and let z=1/y, we have
1
----------------------------------
/ \
ln | lim ((1+1/y)^y) |
\y→∞ /
The limit there is the literal definition of e, so the expression is 1/ln(e), which is 1. Now the proof is complete, the derivative of A^x is A^x*ln(x)

Find the number e by following reasoning. For some base e, the expression e^dt-1/dt = 1, thus de^t/dt = e^t for all t. For t = 0 you find e^t = 1 and slope de^t/dt = 1. Hence approximate e^t = 1+t for small t. Compute e^1 by writing it as e^(10000/10000) = [e^(1/10000)]^10000. Since t = 1/10000 is small, use approximation e^1=[1+1/10000]^10000 ~ 2.718.

Another example of exponential curve: the discharge of a capacitor in a resistive load. At first, the capacitor loose voltage fast. Then, the closer it is fully discharged, the slower the voltage decrease. If we use very precise instruments, we could claim that it tend toward 0 volt but never completely reach it.

The current flowing thru a resistor is computed with ohm law: I = V/R
R is assumed constant, for example 1 ohm
V is the voltage coming from the capacitor, for example 10 volt
The initial current is 10 volt / 1 ohm = 10 Amp
And the power dissipated by the resistor is P = V * I = 10 V * 1 Amp = 10 Watt
Note: because I selected a 1 ohm resistor, the voltage and the power will be represented by the same numeric value. It is a convenient "coincidence" in the same way as using "plank constants" as scale factor allow to simplify some equations.

At 1 millisecond, the voltage is half, 5 Volt
At 2 millisecond, the voltage is half, 2.5 volt
At 4 millisecond, the voltage is halt, 1.25 volt

In practice, electric engineer pick a ratio where they say a capacitor is fully "discharged" when the voltage reach 10% or 1% of full scale. What is the "truth"? It depend on the context. If the capacitor is used at the input of a 12 bit DAC, then the 1% rule would be too imprecise. It would represent a change of 1 bit on a seven bit ADC (value 0 to 127), so it would be equivalent to waste 12 bit - 7 bit : 5 bits of wasted precision.

For the 12 bit ADC, instead of 1%, we need 2^5: 32 times better precision to get a stable voltage that fully reflect the precision capability of the ADC.

To those that are struggling to keep track of the questions or struggling to follow the chain of logic, here is my summary of the key points:

What happens with small nudges to exponential functions?
Observe that the function's derivative is the function itself times a constant and notice that these constants have a relationship.

What is this relationship?
We ask is there a base whose proportionality constant equals 1?, that is, is there an exponential function whose derivative equals itself?

By definition this is e, and the reason it answers the question is because it allows us to think differently about functions whose derivatives are proportional to themselves.

Using the chain rule and our knowledge that d(e^t)/dt = e^t we can explore what happens when we take d(e^c*t)/dt which equals c*e^c*t

Then observing that equations such as 2 = e^ln2 can be lead to 2^t = e^ln2*t and by taking the derivative of the right hand side, which becomes ln2*e^ln2*t and therefore on the left we must have ln2*2^t, we can conclude that the proportionality constant in question must be ln2.

Therefore, the derivative of the exponential function is the original exponential function times the natural log of its base.

You missed something at 7:40
We can prove there is a number whose constant is 1
Take the constant as a function of the base of the exponential function. For example c(2) is 0.6931.., c(1) is 0, c(8) is 2.0794.... Then you realize that c(8) = 3*c(2), as well as c(4) = 2*c(2). Via induction, you could say that c(a^x)=x*c(a)

So, if you want a number "b" whose constant is "h"...
c(b)=h
c(a^(log_a-b)=h a is any positive number =/=1
log_a-b*c(a)=h
log_a-b=h/c(a)
b= a^(h/c(a))

For every number "h", there is a number "b" given by the formula a^(h/c(a)) where a is any positive number =/=1 such as "h" is the constant of "b"

We want to find a number whose constant is 1
b=a^(1/c(a))

Then we replace "a" by any positive number =/= 1. The result will be the same.
Let's say a=2 because we know what the constant of 2 is

b=2^(1/c(2))
b=2^(1/0.6931..)
b=2^1.4426..
b=2.71828...

And we call this number whose constant is 1, e

SPOILER ALERT:
c(a)=ln(a)

Short proof that e is the base of the function a^x for whom (a^dx-1)/dx=1, based on the identity lim n->inf( 1+1/n)^n=e:

(a^dx-1)/dx = 1

dx = a^dx -1

dx +1 = a^dx

(1+dx)^(1/dx)= a

1/dx=n, n->infinity because dx -> 0

lim n->inf (1+1/n)^n=a
a=e

Q.E.D.

I really like the fact that you relate e to pi. When I was learning calculus I was trying to grasp why I should give a damn about e. Pi was easy to understand, it is the ratio of the circumference of the circle to its diameter, and circles are used everywhere in math. Easy to understand pi was just some arbitrary constant that helps everywhere else in math where circles are involved. However with e I was just taught that it is the limit of the compound interest formula, which still made ZERO sense as to why I should learn it. Your video simply explains that e is what basically defines exponential functions, which provides an easy understanding as to what makes the number so important.

Here's the way I thought of it when I was a math grad student: It's all about integrating the function f(x) = 1/x. The number "e" is that number y with property that the integral from 1 to y of 1/x dx is 1. The exponential function exp(x) is the inverse of the function log(y) = the integral from 1 to y of 1/x dx.

Simple enough.

Wonderful video, as usual.
As for a more "intuitive" approach (which lends itself to a more geometric presentation). I think the problem here is that it's the explanation is "backwards". I would go something along these lines:
"In the last videos we looked at ways of calculating derivatives from given functions. However, very often real problems are stated in reverse: we know the derivative (or some property of it) of an unknown function. This leads to "differential equations", now thi is a complicated, involved topic in the general case. However, we'll be looking at a "simple" example now, as an introduction and because this case is related to a very important type of function and its derivative.
Now you introduce some example: population, where the more people you have the more may be born, investement, cooling, radioactive decay, ..."
In all those cases the more we have of a quantity, the faster that quantity will change (increasing or decreasing). This leads to this differential equation.
As usual in this series, we are not going to solve this equation symbolically, we'll look at what the unknown function may look like.
You go on to a nice animation showing that (for integers) we get a quantity that gets multiplied over and over again (exponential). So the mystery function coincides with exponenation for integers (and also rationals) but would be a continuous function that would interpolate irrational numbers. We may decide to define exponentation for irrationals (what we do not know how to do) by means of that function [we'll need a way to evaluate its value in that case, but this is a topic we'll go back to later in the series], anyway we do know what its graphic would look like. This is a very useful use of calculus, expanding functions, [note, we can also go on to define exponentiation for complex numbers using a similar idea, link to your nice videos about the topic).
So, any differential equation of this particular type can be solved with an exponential in some base, we may ask "what's the relationship between the constant in the equation and the base". Trying some values we get very strange answers, for example, for the base to be 2 the constant must be 0,..., for it to be 3, it must be .... There doesn't seem to be a pattern here.
We can get a better understanding if you try a related question: what base would we get if the constant was 1?" In that case, we are looking for a function whose derivative is not only proportional but identical to itself! If we zero in on an answer (by trying values around that point) we get a value of 2,.... Yes! that's the famous numer e! In reality, this is no coincidence. We may thing that this is exactly what the number e is all about! Its definition, just as pi is the ratio of diameter to area, ....

Here's another way of looking at it: If we define f(a) = lim[dt → 0] (a^dt - 1)/dt to be that proportionality constant for the derivative of a^t, you can directly prove the identity f(ab) = f(a) + f(b). (Hint: (ab)^dt = (a^dt b^dt - b^dt) + (b^dt - 1).) which should give a pretty good idea that f is some logarithmic function. Then e is defined such that f(e) = 1, so f must be the natural logarithm.

An interesting fact is that the number e only seems strange to us because we choose to write it in base 10 !

If we choose a different (Mixed radix) numeral system, it seems much more natural.
For instance, in the factorial number system the number e is written as: 10.011111111111... recurring. This is due to the series expression of the number e as the sum 1/0! + 1/1! + 1/2! ...
There is also a very nice visual representation of the factorial base as a branching tree on the number line, in which each branch represents a different digit, and the radix (number of branches) increases with each new digit.

It makes you wonder whether there is a natural base in which pi is written in a simple manner.

More information about the Factorial number system: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Factorial_number_system
And a discussion about the visual representation of factorials: https://math.stackexchange.com/questions/1383150/visualizing-the-factorial

Speaking about the (2^dt-1)/dt constant, if we substitute 2^dt-1=u, then dt=log_2 (u+1), which makes the expression become
u/log_2 (1+u), using logarithm properties we can rewrite it as 1/log_2 (1+u)^1/u . As dt->0, 2^dt-1 also goes to 0, therefore u->0. This here explains another commonly used definition of the number e as lim n->0 of (1+n)^1/n

One problem with your approach is that you haven't defined what 2^t is at the start of your video, for non-integer values of t. The standard way is to define e^t first, as the unique function that equals its own derivative, then define ln(t) as the inverse of this function, and finally define other powers like 2^t in terms of e^t and ln(t), in other words what you did at 10:11 is the definition of the function 2^t.

A very nice trick to use on that last numerical part on "figuring out" the derivative of 2^t is to note that since 1=2^0 we can rewrite
(2^{dt}-1)/dt
as
(2^{dt}-2^0)/dt
then we can see that this constant is simply the derivative of 2^t at t=0.
This tells us that not only the rate of growth of a^x is proportional to itself, but also that it's actually itself times the rate of growth at the start of the process (t=0).
